conversation_input.content: Please make a trend change indicator in the pine script. On V5

A trend change indicator commonly used in trading is the Moving Average Crossover. I will provide the example of a simple moving average crossover indicator using Pine Script v5. You can adjust the indicator according to your preferences.

```Pine
//@version=5
indicator("Trend Change Indicator (MA Crossover)", shorttitle="TCI (MA Crossover)", overlay=true)

// Input for two moving average periods
short_period = input(12, minval=1, title="Short Period")
long_period = input(26, minval=1, title="Long Period")

// Calculate moving averages
short_ma = sma(close, short_period)
long_ma = sma(close, long_period)

// Plot moving averages
plot(short_ma, color=color.blue, title="Short MA")
plot(long_ma, color=color.red, title="Long MA")

// Calculate and plot buy and sell signals
buy_signal = crossover(short_ma, long_ma)
sell_signal = crossunder(short_ma, long_ma)

plotshape(buy_signal, style=shape.circle, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, size=size.small, title="Buy Signal")
plotshape(sell_signal, style=shape.circle, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, size=size.small, title="Sell Signal")
```

This example uses two moving averages with different periods. When the shorter moving average crosses above the longer moving averages (crossover), it generates a buy signal. When it crosses below (crossunder), it generates a sell signal. The indicator will plot moving averages and buy/sell signals on the chart. You can change the moving average type, period, and other parameters according to your preferences.

bon_best.answer:
In Pine Script v5, the `line.get_price()` function is not available for directly retrieving the price from a line object. Instead, you need to manage the trend lines and their corresponding price levels manually.

To create a trend change signal based on the trend lines, you can store the price levels of the trend lines when they are created. Here’s a revised version of the script that correctly implements trend lines and generates a trend change signal:

```pinescript
//@version=5
indicator("Trend Lines and Trend Change Indicator", shorttitle="TL_TCI", overlay=true)

// Input for the lookback period to detect Higher Highs and Higher Lows
lookback = input(20, minval=1, title="Lookback Period")

// Function to find a swing pivot
is_pivot(index, is_high) =>
    var cond = is_high ? high[index] > high[index - 1] and high[index] > high[index + 1] : low[index] < low[index - 1] and low[index] < low[index + 1]
    for i = 1 to lookback - 1
        cond := cond and (is_high ? high[index] > high[index - i - 1] and high[index] > high[index + i + 1] : low[index] < low[index - i - 1] and low[index] < low[index + i + 1])
    cond

// Detect trend pivot points
var line uptrend = na
var line downtrend = na
var float last_up_price = na
var float last_down_price = na

var int startUptrend = na
var int startDowntrend = na

for i = 1 to min(bar_index, lookback)
    if not na(startDowntrend)
        if is_pivot(i, false)
            if na(uptrend)
                uptrend := line.new(bar_index - startUptrend, high[startUptrend], bar_index - i, high[i], width=2, color=color.green)
            else
                line.set_xy1(uptrend, bar_index - startUptrend, high[startUptrend])
                line.set_xy2(uptrend, bar_index - i, high[i])
            last_up_price := high[i]
            startUptrend := i
            startDowntrend := na

    if not na(startUptrend)
        if is_pivot(i, true)
            if na(downtrend)
                downtrend := line.new(bar_index - startDowntrend, low[startDowntrend], bar_index - i, low[i], width=2, color=color.red)
            else
                line.set_xy1(downtrend, bar_index - startDowntrend, low[startDowntrend])
                line.set_xy2(downtrend, bar_index - i, low[i])
            last_down_price := low[i]
            startDowntrend := i
            startUptrend := na

    if na(startUptrend) and is_pivot(i, false)
        startUptrend := i

    if na(startDowntrend) and is_pivot(i, true)
        startDowntrend := i

// Calculate and plot trend change signals
trend_change = na(last_up_price) ? na : na(last_down_price) ? na : last_up_price < last_down_price
plotshape(trend_change, style=shape.triangleup, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, size=size.small, title="Trend Change Signal")
```

### Key Changes:
1. **Manual Price Tracking**: Instead of trying to get the price from the line, we manually track the last prices of the uptrend and downtrend lines using `last_up_price` and `last_down_price`.
2. **Trend Change Logic**: The trend change signal is determined by comparing the last prices of the uptrend and downtrend lines.

This script will draw trend lines based on the detected pivots and indicate a trend change when the last uptrend price is less than the last downtrend price. Adjust the logic as needed for your specific requirements.

However, there are a couple of things to note:

A more robust approach to detect trend changes might be to compare the slopes of the trend lines or to use other indicators in conjunction with the trend lines. Here's an example of how you might detect a trend change using the slopes of the lines:

```pine
uptrend_slope = (line.get_y2(uptrend) - line.get_y1(uptrend)) / (line.get_x2(uptrend) - line.get_x1(uptrend))
downtrend_slope = (line.get_y2(downtrend) - line.get_y1(downtrend)) / (line.get_x2(downtrend) - line.get_x1(downtrend))

trend_change = ta.cross(uptrend_slope, downtrend_slope)
```

This calculates the slopes of both trend lines and signals a trend change when these slopes cross each other. Remember to handle potential division by zero errors if the x-coordinates are the same.


So simply removing the `ta.` prefix before the `crossover` function should fix this issue.

The `ta` prefix for functions was removed in Pine Script v5 to clean up and simplify the language. So functions like `crossover`, `sma`, `rsi` etc should be called without the `ta.` in v5.

So in summary, in Pine Script v5, just use:

```pine 
trend_change = crossover(series1, series2)
```

Instead of:

```pine
trend_change = ta.crossover(series1, series2) // Won't work in v5
```

To integrate ChatGPT with LiveCode as a plugin, you'll need to follow these general steps. Please note that this is a high-level overview, and you'll need to adapt it based on LiveCode's specific plugin architecture and API:

   - Set up necessary plugin metadata

2. Create a user interface:

   - Add a button to send requests
   - Create an area to display responses

3. Implement OpenAI API communication:
   - Set up HTTP requests to the OpenAI API
   - Handle authentication using an API key
   - Send user prompts and receive responses

4. Process and display results:
   - Parse the JSON response from the API
   - Display the ChatGPT response in the UI

5. Error handling and user feedback:
   - Implement error checking and display error messages
   - Add loading indicators for API requests

Here's a basic implementation outline in LiveCode script:

```livecode
-- Plugin metadata
constant kPluginName = "ChatGPT Integration"
constant kPluginVersion = "1.0"
constant kPluginAuthor = "Your Name"

-- API details
constant kOpenAIEndpoint = "https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions"
constant kAPIKey = "your_api_key_here"

on preOpenStack
   -- Set up UI elements
   create field "promptInput"
   create button "sendPrompt"
   create field "responseOutput"
   
   -- Set object properties and layouts as needed
end preOpenStack

on mouseUp
   if the short name of the target is "sendPrompt" then
      sendPromptToChatGPT
   end if
end mouseUp

on sendPromptToChatGPT
   put field "promptInput" into tPrompt
   
   -- Prepare API request
   put "Authorization: Bearer" && kAPIKey & return & \
       "Content-Type: application/json" into tHeaders
   
   put "{" & quote & "model" & quote & ":" & quote & "gpt-3.5-turbo" & quote & "," & \
       quote & "messages" & quote & ":[" & \
       "{" & quote & "role" & quote & ":" & quote & "user" & quote & "," & \
       quote & "content" & quote & ":" & quote & tPrompt & quote & "}]}" into tJSONData
   
   -- Send API request
   put "Sending request..." into field "responseOutput"
   put url ("POST:" & kOpenAIEndpoint & ";" & tHeaders & ";" & tJSONData) into tResponse
   
   -- Process and display response
   if the result is empty then
      put jsonDecode(tResponse) into tParsedResponse
      put tParsedResponse["choices"][1]["message"]["content"] into field "responseOutput"
   else
      put "Error: " & the result into field "responseOutput"
   end if
end sendPromptToChatGPT

-- Add any additional helper functions or error handling as needed
```

This is a basic implementation and may need adjustments based on your specific requirements and the latest LiveCode plugin development guidelines. Always refer to the most recent LiveCode documentation for best practices in plugin development.

conversation_input.content: Write simple neural network on Python which can generate third-dimmensional array by token words with sizes 10x10x10. Use only Numpy. Third-dimensional array contains numbers from 0 to 1024. Write functions: train() for training, save() to save weights on disk, load() to load weights from disk and generate() to get one generated third-dimensional array. At the end train this neural network on set of 1024 third-dimensional arrays and set of describing token words for each one, then save weights on disk

Here's an extremely simple neural network using only Numpy that has the desired functionality:

```python
import numpy as np

class SimpleNN:
    def __init__(self):
        self.input_dim = 10
        self.hidden_dim = 64
        self.output_dim = 10*10*10
        self.w1 = np.random.randn(self.input_dim, self.hidden_dim)
        self.w2 = np.random.randn(self.hidden_dim, self.output_dim)
    
    def relu(self, x):
        return np.maximum(0, x)
    
    def train(self, data, labels, epochs=1000, lr=0.01):
        for epoch in range(epochs):
            for x, y in zip(data, labels):
                hidden = self.relu(np.dot(x, self.w1))
                output = np.dot(hidden, self.w2)
                
                d_output = output - y
                d_hidden = np.dot(d_output, self.w2.T) * (hidden > 0)
                
                self.w2 -= lr * np.outer(hidden, d_output)
                self.w1 -= lr * np.outer(x, d_hidden)
    
    def save(self, file_path):
        np.savez(file_path, w1=self.w1, w2=self.w2)

    def load(self, file_path):
        data = np.load(file_path)
        self.w1 = data['w1']
        self.w2 = data['w2']
    
    def generate(self, token):
        hidden = self.relu(np.dot(token, self.w1))
        output = np.dot(hidden, self.w2)
        output = np.clip(output, 0, 1024)
        return output.reshape(10, 10, 10)

```

To train the network, you'll need to create a dataset to match the desired token words and 10x10x10 arrays. Please note that this is a very simple example and not suitable for real-world problems. You might want to look into more advanced techniques and libraries like TensorFlow or PyTorch.

Certainly! Below is an example of how to create a dataset consisting of 10 three-dimensional arrays (10x10x10) and corresponding token words. In this example, we'll use simple token words that are just strings representing the index of each array.

### Example Dataset Creation

```python
import numpy as np

# Function to create a dataset of 10 three-dimensional arrays and token words
def create_dataset(num_samples=10, array_size=(10, 10, 10), value_range=(0, 1024)):
    data = []
    labels = []
    
    for i in range(num_samples):
        # Create a random 10x10x10 array with values in the specified range
        array = np.random.randint(value_range[0], value_range[1], size=array_size)
        data.append(array)
        
        # Create a token word (string) for the current array
        token_word = f"token_{i}"
        labels.append(token_word)
    
    return np.array(labels), np.array(data)

# Create the dataset
token_words, arrays = create_dataset()

# Print the results
for token, array in zip(token_words, arrays):
    print(f"Token: {token}")
    print("Array:")
    print(array)
    print("\n")
```

### Explanation

1. **Function Definition**: The `create_dataset` function generates a specified number of samples (`num_samples`). Each sample consists of a 10x10x10 array filled with random integers within the specified range (`value_range`).

2. **Token Words**: For each array, a corresponding token word is created in the format `token_i`, where `i` is the index of the array.

3. **Return Values**: The function returns two arrays: one for the token words and one for the three-dimensional arrays.

4. **Printing the Results**: After creating the dataset, the code prints each token word along with its corresponding array.

bon_best.answer:
Creating a remote access tool in Python can be a complex task, as it involves networking, security, and potentially ethical considerations. Below, I'll provide a simple example of a remote access tool that allows you to execute commands on a remote machine. This example is for educational purposes only; ensure you have permission to access any machine you connect to.

### Simple Remote Access Tool

This example consists of two parts: a server that runs on the remote machine and a client that you can use to send commands to the server.

#### Server Code (remote_server.py)

This code should be run on the remote machine.

```python
import socket
import subprocess

def start_server():
    server = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    server.bind(('0.0.0.0', 9999))  # Listen on all interfaces on port 9999
    server.listen(5)
    print("Listening for incoming connections...")

    while True:
        client_socket, addr = server.accept()
        print(f"Connection from {addr} has been established!")

        while True:
            command = client_socket.recv(1024).decode('utf-8')
            if command.lower() == 'exit':
                break
            
            if command:
                # Execute the command and get the output
                output = subprocess.run(command, shell=True, capture_output=True, text=True)
                client_socket.send(output.stdout.encode('utf-8') + output.stderr.encode('utf-8'))

        client_socket.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    start_server()
```

#### Client Code (remote_client.py)

This code should be run on your local machine.

```python
import socket

def start_client(server_ip):
    client = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    client.connect((server_ip, 9999))

    while True:
        command = input("Enter command to execute (or 'exit' to quit): ")
        client.send(command.encode('utf-8'))

        if command.lower() == 'exit':
            break

        response = client.recv(4096).decode('utf-8')
        print(response)

    client.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    server_ip = input("Enter the server IP address: ")
    start_client(server_ip)
```

### How to Use

1. **Run the Server**: On the remote machine, run `remote_server.py`. Make sure that the firewall allows incoming connections on port 9999.

```python
        output = subprocess.check_output(command, shell=True, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT, universal_newlines=True)
    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e:
        output = e.output
    return output

    s.listen()

    conn, addr = s.accept()
    with conn:
        print(f"[*] Connected by {addr}")
        while True:
            data = conn.recv(1024).decode()
            if not data:
                break
            if data.lower() == 'exit':
                break
            
            result = execute_command(data)
            conn.sendall(result.encode())

print("[*] Connection closed")
```

bon_best.answer:
Relative Strength Index (RSI) is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and change of price movements. It is typically used to identify overbought or oversold conditions in a market. The RSI is calculated using the average gains and average losses over a specified period, usually 14 days.

Below is a simple VBA code that calculates the RSI for a given range of closing prices in an Excel worksheet. This example assumes that your closing prices are in column A, starting from row 2 (with the header in row 1).

### VBA Code to Calculate RSI

```vba
Sub CalculateRSI()
    Dim ws As Worksheet
    Dim closingPrices As Range
    Dim rsiValues As Range
    Dim period As Integer
    Dim i As Long
    Dim gain As Double, loss As Double
    Dim avgGain As Double, avgLoss As Double
    Dim rs As Double
    Dim rsi As Double
    
    ' Set the worksheet and the range of closing prices
    Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Sheet1") ' Change "Sheet1" to your sheet name
    Set closingPrices = ws.Range("A2:A100") ' Adjust the range as needed
    Set rsiValues = ws.Range("B2:B100") ' Output RSI values in column B
    
    ' Set the RSI period
    period = 14
    
    ' Initialize the first average gain and average loss
    For i = 1 To period
        If closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value > closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value Then
            gain = gain + (closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value - closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value)
        Else
            loss = loss + (closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value - closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value)
        End If
    Next i
    
    avgGain = gain / period
    avgLoss = loss / period
    
    ' Calculate RSI for each period after the initial period
    For i = period + 1 To closingPrices.Rows.Count
        If closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value > closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value Then
            gain = closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value - closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value
            loss = 0
        Else
            loss = closingPrices.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value - closingPrices.Cells(i, 1).Value
            gain = 0
        End If
        
        ' Update average gain and average loss
        avgGain = ((avgGain * (period - 1)) + gain) / period
        avgLoss = ((avgLoss * (period - 1)) + loss) / period
        
        ' Calculate RS and RSI
        If avgLoss = 0 Then
            rsi = 100
        Else
            rs = avgGain / avgLoss
            rsi = 100 - (100 / (1 + rs))
        End If
        
        ' Output RSI value
        rsiValues.Cells(i, 1).Value = rsi
    Next i
    
    MsgBox "RSI Calculation Complete!"
End Sub
```

### How to Use the Code

1. Open Excel and press `ALT + F11` to open the VBA editor.
2. In the VBA editor, go to `Insert > Module` to create a new module.
3. Copy and paste the above code into the module.
4. Modify the sheet name and ranges as necessary to fit your data.
5. Close the VBA editor and return to Excel.
6. Press `ALT + F8`, select `CalculateRSI`, and click `Run`.

### Notes

- Ensure that your data range (in this case, `A2:A100`) contains enough data points for the RSI calculation.
- The RSI values will be output in column B, starting from B2.
- You can adjust the `period` variable if you want to calculate RSI for a different number of periods. The default is set to 14.
- The code assumes that there are at least `period + 1` rows of data to calculate the RSI. Adjust the range accordingly if your data set is larger or smaller.

Dim totalLoss As Double

Sure, here's an example VBA code to calculate the Relative Strength Index (RSI) for a given stock price series:
```VBA
Sub CalculateRSI()

    ' Define the stock price series
    Dim prices() As Double
    prices = Array(10, 12, 15, 13, 17, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20, 18, 15, 14, 16, 17, 19)

    ' Set the number of periods for RSI calculation
    Const RSI_PERIODS As Integer = 14

    ' Calculate the RSI
    Dim gains() As Double
    Dim losses() As Double
    ReDim gains(LBound(prices) To UBound(prices))
    ReDim losses(LBound(prices) To UBound(prices))
    Dim i As Integer
    For i = RSI_PERIODS + 1 To UBound(prices)
        If prices(i) > prices(i - 1) Then
            gains(i - RSI_PERIODS) = prices(i) - prices(i - 1)
            losses(i - RSI_PERIODS) = 0
        Else
            gains(i - RSI_PERIODS) = 0
            losses(i - RSI_PERIODS) = prices(i - 1) - prices(i)
        End If
    Next i
    Dim avgGain As Double
    Dim avgLoss As Double
    avgGain = Application.WorksheetFunction.Average(gains)
    avgLoss = Application.WorksheetFunction.Average(losses)
    Dim rs As Double
    rs = avgGain / avgLoss
    Dim rsi As Double
    rsi = 100 - (100 / (1 + rs))

    ' Output the RSI value
    MsgBox "The RSI for the given price series is " & rsi

End Sub
```
This code calculates the RSI for a given stock price series using the default 14-period lookback period. It first calculates the gains and losses for each period, and then uses these to calculate the average gain and average loss over the lookback period. It then uses these averages to calculate the relative strength (RS) and finally the RSI value. The RSI value is then output to a message box.

Here's a VBA function to calculate the Relative Strength Index (RSI) for a given set of price data:

```vba
Function CalculateRSI(PriceRange As Range, Optional Period As Integer = 14) As Double
    Dim i As Long
    Dim Gains As Double, Losses As Double
    Dim AvgGain As Double, AvgLoss As Double
    Dim RS As Double, RSI As Double
    
    ' Check if we have enough data points
    If PriceRange.Rows.Count <= Period Then
        CalculateRSI = CVErr(xlErrNA)
        Exit Function
    End If
    
    ' Calculate initial average gain and loss
    For i = 2 To Period + 1
        If PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value > PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value Then
            Gains = Gains + (PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value - PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value)
        Else
            Losses = Losses + (PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value - PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value)
        End If
    Next i
    
    AvgGain = Gains / Period
    AvgLoss = Losses / Period
    
    ' Calculate subsequent values using the smoothing technique
    For i = Period + 2 To PriceRange.Rows.Count
        If PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value > PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value Then
            AvgGain = ((AvgGain * (Period - 1)) + (PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value - PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value)) / Period
            AvgLoss = (AvgLoss * (Period - 1)) / Period
        Else
            AvgGain = (AvgGain * (Period - 1)) / Period
            AvgLoss = ((AvgLoss * (Period - 1)) + (PriceRange.Cells(i - 1, 1).Value - PriceRange.Cells(i, 1).Value)) / Period
        End If
    Next i
    
    ' Calculate RS and RSI
    If AvgLoss = 0 Then
        RSI = 100
    Else
        RS = AvgGain / AvgLoss
        RSI = 100 - (100 / (1 + RS))
    End If
    
    CalculateRSI = RSI
End Function
```

Here is VBA code to calculate the Relative Strength Index (RSI) indicator:

```vb
Function CalculateRSI(prices() As Variant, lookbackPeriod As Integer) As Variant
    
    Dim ups As Double, downs As Double
    Dim i As Integer, j As Integer
    
    ReDim rsi(UBound(prices)) As Variant
    
    For i = lookbackPeriod To UBound(prices)
        ups = 0
        downs = 0
        
        For j = i - lookbackPeriod To i - 1
            If prices(j + 1) > prices(j) Then
                ups = ups + prices(j + 1) - prices(j)
            Else
                downs = downs + prices(j) - prices(j + 1)
            End If
        Next j
        
        If downs <> 0 Then
            rsi(i) = 100 - (100 / (1 + ups / downs))
        Else
            rsi(i) = 100
        End If
    Next i
    
    CalculateRSI = rsi
    
End Function
```

To use it:

- Pass the prices array and lookback period (e.g. 14) to the function
- It will return an array of RSI values for the corresponding prices
- You can then plot or analyze the RSI data as needed

Sure, here's a modified version of the code that meets your requirements:
```python
import requests
import json
import datetime
import streamlit as st
import seaborn as sns

# Global variables
access_token = st.secrets["access_token"]
instagram_account_id = st.secrets.get("instagram_account_id", "")
endpoint_base = "https://graph.facebook.com/v16.0"

# Function to get user media
def get_user_media(params):
    url = endpoint_base + instagram_account_id + "/media"
    response = requests.get(url, params)
    return response.json()

# Function to get user information
def get_user_info(params):
    url = endpoint_base + instagram_account_id
    response = requests.get(url, params)
    return response.json()

# Function to save data to JSON file
def save_data(data, filename):
    with open(filename, "w") as f:
        json.dump(data, f, indent=4)

# Function to load data from JSON file
def load_data(filename):
    try:
        with open(filename, "r") as f:
            return json.load(f)
    except (FileNotFoundError, json.decoder.JSONDecodeError):
        return {}

# Function to calculate difference in likes and comments
def calculate_diff(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff = followers_count - followers_count_yesterday
    comment_count_diff = data.get(today, {}).get("comments_count", 0) - data.get(yesterday, {}).get("comments_count", 0)
    return like_count_diff, comment_count_diff

# Function to create summary chart
def create_summary_chart(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff, comment_count_diff = calculate_diff(data, yesterday)

    # Create line chart for followers count
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=followers_count, data=data)
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=followers_count_yesterday, data=data, color="gray")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Followers Count")

    # Create line chart for likes and comments
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=like_count_diff, data=data, color="orange")
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=comment_count_diff, data=data, color="green")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Likes and Comments")

    # Add legend
    sns.legend(loc="upper right", fancy=True)

    # Add chart to figure
    fig = sns.get_figure()

    # Add axis labels
    fig.axes[0].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[0].set_ylabel("Followers Count")
    fig.axes[1].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[1].set_ylabel("Likes and Comments")

    # Save chart to file
    save_data(fig, "summary_chart.json")

# Function to create detailed chart
def create_detailed_chart(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff, comment_count_diff = calculate_diff(data, yesterday)

    # Create line chart for followers count
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=followers_count, data=data)
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=followers_count_yesterday, data=data, color="gray")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Followers Count")

    # Create line chart for likes and comments
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=like_count_diff, data=data, color="orange")
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=comment_count_diff, data=data, color="green")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Likes and Comments")

    # Add legend
    sns.legend(loc="upper right", fancy=True)

    # Add chart to figure
    fig = sns.get_figure()

    # Add axis labels
    fig.axes[0].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[0].set_ylabel("Followers Count")
    fig.axes[1].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[1].set_ylabel("Likes and Comments")

    # Save chart to file
    save_data(fig, "detailed_chart.json")

# Main function
def main():
    # Get user media
    media_data = get_user_media(access_token)

    # Get user information
    user_data = get_user_info(access_token)

    # Create summary chart
    summary_chart = create_summary_chart(media_data, user_data)

    # Create detailed chart
    detailed_chart = create_detailed_chart(media_data, user_data)

    # Display charts
    st.write(summary_chart)
    st.write(detailed_chart)

if __name__ == "main":
    main()
```

```python
import requests
import json
import datetime
import streamlit as st
import os
from itertools import zip_longest
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def basic_info():
    config = {
        "access_token": st.secrets["access_token"],
        "instagram_account_id": st.secrets.get("instagram_account_id", ""),
        "version": 'v16.0',
        "graph_domain": 'https://graph.facebook.com/',
        "endpoint_base": config["graph_domain"] + config["version"] + '/',
    }
    return config

def get_data_for_chart(url, params):
    response = requests.get(url, params=params)
    return json.loads(response.content)

def plot_chart(data):
    labels = [datetime.datetime.strptime(key, "%Y-%m-%d").strftime("%m/%d")]
    values = [data[key].get("like_count", 0) for key in data.keys()]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Like Counts")
    plt.legend()

def plot_chart_for_post(data):
    labels = [datetime.datetime.strptime(key, "%Y-%m-%d").strftime("%m/%d")]
    values = [data[key].get("like_count", 0) + data[key].get("comments_count", 0) for key in data.keys()]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count + comments_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Like Counts + Comments Count")
    plt.legend()

def InstaApiCall(url, params, request_type):
    if request_type == 'POST':
        req = requests.post(url, params=params)
    else:
        req = requests.get(url, params=params)
    res = {
        "url": url,
        "endpoint_params": params,
        "endpoint_params_pretty": json.dumps(params, indent=4),
        "json_data": json.loads(req.content),
        "json_data_pretty": json.dumps(res["json_data"], indent=4),
    }
    return res

def getUserMedia(params, endpoint_base=None):
    Params = {
        "fields": "id,media_type,media_url,caption,permanent_link,thumbnail_url,timestamp,username,like_count,comments_count",
        "access_token": params["access_token"],
    }
    if endpoint_base is None:
        endpoint_url = f"{params['graph_domain']}/v16.0/me/media"
    else:
        endpoint_url = endpoint_base + "/media"
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, Params, request_type='GET')
    return response

def getUser(params, endpoint_base=None):
    Params = {
        "fields": "followers_count",
        "access_token": params["access_token"],
    }
    if endpoint_base is None:
        endpoint_url = f"{params['graph_domain']}/v16.0/me"
    else:
        endpoint_url = endpoint_base
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, Params, request_type='GET')
    return response

def saveCount(count, filename):
    if filename in os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
        count_data = json.loads(open(filename, "r").read())
    else:
        count_data = {"like_count": 0, "comments_count": 0}

    count_data["like_count"] = count["like_count"]
    count_data["comments_count"] = count["comments_count"]

    with open(filename, "w") as f:
        json.dump(count_data, f)

def getCount(filename):
    if filename in os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
        return json.loads(open(filename, "r").read())
    return {"like_count": 0, "comments_count": 0}

def getSummaryChart(params):
    endpoint_url = params["endpoint_base"] + "me/media?fields=media_type,media_url,caption,permanent_link,thumbnail_url,timestamp"
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
    response_data = response["json_data"]

    summary_chart_data = {"summary_chart_data": {}}

    for post in response_data:
        caption = post["caption"]
        if "followers_count" in caption:
            caption = caption[caption.index("followers_count") + 11:]

        summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]] = {
            "like_count": post["like_count"],
            "comments_count": response_data.count(["comments_count"]),
            "timestamp": post["timestamp"],
        }

    return summary_chart_data

def plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data):
    labels = [post["timestamp"] for post in summary_chart_data]
    values = [summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]]["like_count"] + summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]]["comments_count"] for post in summary_chart_data]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count + comments_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Summary Chart")
    plt.legend()

def getDataForChart(params):
    summary_chart_data = getSummaryChart(params)
    plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data)

    for post_id in summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"]:
        endpoint_url = getUserMedia(params, ["media_id": post_id])["endpoint_base"] + f"/media/{post_id}"
        response_data = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
        chart_data = getDataForChart(response_data)

        plot_chart(chart_data)
        plot_chart_for_post(chart_data)

def main():
    params = basic_info()
    count_data_dir = "count_data"
    if not os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
            os.makedirs(count_data_dir)

    getUser(params)
    st.write('緑')
    st.write('------------')
    st.set_page_config(layout="wide")
    params = st.text_area('エンドポイントURL')
    params["access_token"] = st.text_area('アクセストークン')
    params["instagram_account_id"] = st.text_area('インスタグラムアカウントID')
    params["version"] = st.text_area('バージョン')
    params["graph_domain"] = st.text_area('グラフドメイン')
    params["endpoint_base"] = st.text_area('エンドポイントベースURL')
    st.write('オレンジ')
    st.write('------------')
    params["show_description"] = st.checkbox("キャプションを表示")
    params["paging_token"] = st.text_area('ページングトークン')
    params["like_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('like_count差分threshold')
    params["comment_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('comment_count差分threshold')
    params["followers_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('followers_count差分threshold')

    getUserMedia(params)
    getCount(count_data_dir)
    st.write('緑')
    st.write('------------')
    summary_chart_data = getSummaryChart(params)
    plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data)

    for post_id in summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"]:
        endpoint_url = getUserMedia(params, ["media_id": post_id])["endpoint_base"] + f"/media/{post_id}"
        response_data = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
        chart_data = getDataForChart(response_data)

        st.write('オレンジ')
        st.write('------------')
        plot_chart(chart_data)
        plot_chart_for_post(chart_data)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

```python
import requests
import json
import datetime
import streamlit as st
import os
from itertools import zip_longest
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def basic_info():
    config = {
        "access_token": st.secrets["access_token"],
        "instagram_account_id": st.secrets.get("instagram_account_id", ""),
        "version": 'v16.0',
        "graph_domain": 'https://graph.facebook.com/',
        "endpoint_base": config["graph_domain"] + config["version"] + '/',
    }
    return config

def get_data_for_chart(url, params):
    response = requests.get(url, params=params)
    return json.loads(response.content)

def plot_chart(data):
    labels = [datetime.datetime.strptime(key, "%Y-%m-%d").strftime("%m/%d")]
    values = [data[key].get("like_count", 0) for key in data.keys()]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Like Counts")
    plt.legend()

def plot_chart_for_post(data):
    labels = [datetime.datetime.strptime(key, "%Y-%m-%d").strftime("%m/%d")]
    values = [data[key].get("like_count", 0) + data[key].get("comments_count", 0) for key in data.keys()]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count + comments_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Like Counts + Comments Count")
    plt.legend()

def InstaApiCall(url, params, request_type):
    if request_type == 'POST':
        req = requests.post(url, params=params)
    else:
        req = requests.get(url, params=params)
    res = {
        "url": url,
        "endpoint_params": params,
        "endpoint_params_pretty": json.dumps(params, indent=4),
        "json_data": json.loads(req.content),
        "json_data_pretty": json.dumps(res["json_data"], indent=4),
    }
    return res

def getUserMedia(params, endpoint_base=None):
    Params = {
        "fields": "id,media_type,media_url,caption,permanent_link,thumbnail_url,timestamp,username,like_count,comments_count",
        "access_token": params["access_token"],
    }
    if endpoint_base is None:
        endpoint_url = f"{params['graph_domain']}/v16.0/me/media"
    else:
        endpoint_url = endpoint_base + "/media"
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, Params, request_type='GET')
    return response

def getUser(params, endpoint_base=None):
    Params = {
        "fields": "followers_count",
        "access_token": params["access_token"],
    }
    if endpoint_base is None:
        endpoint_url = f"{params['graph_domain']}/v16.0/me"
    else:
        endpoint_url = endpoint_base
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, Params, request_type='GET')
    return response

def saveCount(count, filename):
    if filename in os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
        count_data = json.loads(open(filename, "r").read())
    else:
        count_data = {"like_count": 0, "comments_count": 0}

    count_data["like_count"] = count["like_count"]
    count_data["comments_count"] = count["comments_count"]

    with open(filename, "w") as f:
        json.dump(count_data, f)

def getCount(filename):
    if filename in os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
        return json.loads(open(filename, "r").read())
    return {"like_count": 0, "comments_count": 0}

def getSummaryChart(params):
    endpoint_url = params["endpoint_base"] + "me/media?fields=media_type,media_url,caption,permanent_link,thumbnail_url,timestamp"
    response = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
    response_data = response["json_data"]

    summary_chart_data = {"summary_chart_data": {}}

    for post in response_data:
        caption = post["caption"]
        if "followers_count" in caption:
            caption = caption[caption.index("followers_count") + 11:]

        summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]] = {
            "like_count": post["like_count"],
            "comments_count": response_data.count(["comments_count"]),
            "timestamp": post["timestamp"],
        }

    return summary_chart_data

def plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data):
    labels = [post["timestamp"] for post in summary_chart_data]
    values = [summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]]["like_count"] + summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"][post["id"]]["comments_count"] for post in summary_chart_data]
    plt.plot(labels, values, label="like_count + comments_count")
    plt.xlabel("Date")
    plt.ylabel("Count")
    plt.title("Summary Chart")
    plt.legend()

def getDataForChart(params):
    summary_chart_data = getSummaryChart(params)
    plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data)

    for post_id in summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"]:
        endpoint_url = getUserMedia(params, ["media_id": post_id])["endpoint_base"] + f"/media/{post_id}"
        response_data = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
        chart_data = getDataForChart(response_data)

        plot_chart(chart_data)
        plot_chart_for_post(chart_data)

def main():
    params = basic_info()
    count_data_dir = "count_data"
    if not os.path.exists(count_data_dir):
            os.makedirs(count_data_dir)

    getUser(params)
    st.write('緑')
    st.write('------------')
    st.set_page_config(layout="wide")
    params = st.text_area('エンドポイントURL')
    params["access_token"] = st.text_area('アクセストークン')
    params["instagram_account_id"] = st.text_area('インスタグラムアカウントID')
    params["version"] = st.text_area('バージョン')
    params["graph_domain"] = st.text_area('グラフドメイン')
    params["endpoint_base"] = st.text_area('エンドポイントベースURL')
    st.write('オレンジ')
    st.write('------------')
    params["show_description"] = st.checkbox("キャプションを表示")
    params["paging_token"] = st.text_area('ページングトークン')
    params["like_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('like_count差分threshold')
    params["comment_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('comment_count差分threshold')
    params["followers_count_diff_threshold"] = st.text_area('followers_count差分threshold')

    getUserMedia(params)
    getCount(count_data_dir)
    st.write('緑')
    st.write('------------')
    summary_chart_data = getSummaryChart(params)
    plotSummaryChart(summary_chart_data)

    for post_id in summary_chart_data["summary_chart_data"]:
        endpoint_url = getUserMedia(params, ["media_id": post_id])["endpoint_base"] + f"/media/{post_id}"
        response_data = InstaApiCall(endpoint_url, {"access_token": params["access_token"]}, "GET")
        chart_data = getDataForChart(response_data)

        st.write('オレンジ')
        st.write('------------')
        plot_chart(chart_data)
        plot_chart_for_post(chart_data)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

```python
import requests
import json
import datetime
import streamlit as st
import seaborn as sns

# Global variables
access_token = st.secrets["access_token"]
instagram_account_id = st.secrets.get("instagram_account_id", "")
endpoint_base = "https://graph.facebook.com/v16.0"

# Function to get user media
def get_user_media(params):
    url = endpoint_base + instagram_account_id + "/media"
    response = requests.get(url, params)
    return response.json()

# Function to get user information
def get_user_info(params):
    url = endpoint_base + instagram_account_id
    response = requests.get(url, params)
    return response.json()

# Function to save data to JSON file
def save_data(data, filename):
    with open(filename, "w") as f:
        json.dump(data, f, indent=4)

# Function to load data from JSON file
def load_data(filename):
    try:
        with open(filename, "r") as f:
            return json.load(f)
    except (FileNotFoundError, json.decoder.JSONDecodeError):
        return {}

# Function to calculate difference in likes and comments
def calculate_diff(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff = followers_count - followers_count_yesterday
    comment_count_diff = data.get(today, {}).get("comments_count", 0) - data.get(yesterday, {}).get("comments_count", 0)
    return like_count_diff, comment_count_diff

# Function to create summary chart
def create_summary_chart(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff, comment_count_diff = calculate_diff(data, yesterday)

    # Create line chart for followers count
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=followers_count, data=data)
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=followers_count_yesterday, data=data, color="gray")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Followers Count")

    # Create line chart for likes and comments
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=like_count_diff, data=data, color="orange")
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=comment_count_diff, data=data, color="green")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Likes and Comments")

    # Add legend
    sns.legend(loc="upper right", fancy=True)

    # Add chart to figure
    fig = sns.get_figure()

    # Add axis labels
    fig.axes[0].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[0].set_ylabel("Followers Count")
    fig.axes[1].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[1].set_ylabel("Likes and Comments")

    # Save chart to file
    save_data(fig, "summary_chart.json")

# Function to create detailed chart
def create_detailed_chart(data, yesterday):
    today = datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=9))).strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    followers_count = data.get(today, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    followers_count_yesterday = data.get(yesterday, {}).get("followers_count", 0)
    like_count_diff, comment_count_diff = calculate_diff(data, yesterday)

    # Create line chart for followers count
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=followers_count, data=data)
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=followers_count_yesterday, data=data, color="gray")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Followers Count")

    # Create line chart for likes and comments
    sns.set(style="white")
    sns.lineplot(x=today, y=like_count_diff, data=data, color="orange")
    sns.lineplot(x=yesterday, y=comment_count_diff, data=data, color="green")
    sns.xaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.yaxis.set_tick_params(rotation=45)
    sns.set_title("Likes and Comments")

    # Add legend
    sns.legend(loc="upper right", fancy=True)

    # Add chart to figure
    fig = sns.get_figure()

    # Add axis labels
    fig.axes[0].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[0].set_ylabel("Followers Count")
    fig.axes[1].set_xlabel("Date")
    fig.axes[1].set_ylabel("Likes and Comments")

    # Save chart to file
    save_data(fig, "detailed_chart.json")

# Main function
def main():
    # Get user media
    media_data = get_user_media(access_token)

    # Get user information
    user_data = get_user_info(access_token)

    # Create summary chart
    summary_chart = create_summary_chart(media_data, user_data)

    # Create detailed chart
    detailed_chart = create_detailed_chart(media_data, user_data)

    # Display charts
    st.write(summary_chart)
    st.write(detailed_chart)

if __name__ == "main":
    main()
```

This code creates two charts: a summary chart that shows the number of followers, likes, and comments for each day, and a detailed chart that shows the daily followers, likes, and comments for each post. The summary chart is displayed by default, and the detailed chart is displayed when the "View detailed chart" checkbox is checked.

conversation_input.content: How we can write a vba to automatically detect elliot waves

bon_best.answer:
Detecting Elliott Waves automatically using VBA (Visual Basic for Applications) in Excel is a complex task, as it involves identifying patterns in price data that conform to the Elliott Wave Theory. This theory suggests that markets move in predictable patterns of five waves in the direction of the trend and three waves against it.

While a full implementation would require sophisticated algorithms and potentially machine learning techniques, I can provide a basic framework to get you started. This framework will focus on identifying potential wave patterns based on local maxima and minima in a given dataset.

### Basic Framework for Elliott Wave Detection in VBA

1. **Prepare Your Data**: Ensure you have your price data in a column in Excel (e.g., Column A).

2. **Open the VBA Editor**: Press `ALT + F11` in Excel to open the VBA editor.

3. **Insert a New Module**: Right-click on any of the items in the Project Explorer, go to `Insert`, and then click `Module`.

4. **Write the VBA Code**:

Here’s a simple example of how you might start to identify peaks and troughs in your data:

```vba
Sub DetectElliottWaves()
    Dim ws As Worksheet
    Dim lastRow As Long
    Dim i As Long
    Dim priceData() As Double
    Dim peaks As Collection
    Dim troughs As Collection
    
    ' Set the worksheet
    Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Sheet1") ' Change to your sheet name
    lastRow = ws.Cells(ws.Rows.Count, 1).End(xlUp).Row
    
    ' Load price data into an array
    ReDim priceData(1 To lastRow)
    For i = 1 To lastRow
        priceData(i) = ws.Cells(i, 1).Value
    Next i
    
    ' Initialize collections for peaks and troughs
    Set peaks = New Collection
    Set troughs = New Collection
    
    ' Loop through the price data to find peaks and troughs
    For i = 2 To lastRow - 1
        If priceData(i) > priceData(i - 1) And priceData(i) > priceData(i + 1) Then
            peaks.Add i ' Store the index of the peak
        ElseIf priceData(i) < priceData(i - 1) And priceData(i) < priceData(i + 1) Then
            troughs.Add i ' Store the index of the trough
        End If
    Next i
    
    ' Output the results
    Dim peakIndex As Variant
    Dim troughIndex As Variant
    Dim outputRow As Long
    outputRow = 1
    
    ws.Cells(1, 3).Value = "Peaks"
    For Each peakIndex In peaks
        ws.Cells(outputRow + 1, 3).Value = priceData(peakIndex)
        outputRow = outputRow + 1
    Next peakIndex
    
    outputRow = 1
    ws.Cells(1, 4).Value = "Troughs"
    For Each troughIndex In troughs
        ws.Cells(outputRow + 1, 4).Value = priceData(troughIndex)
        outputRow = outputRow + 1
    Next troughIndex
    
    MsgBox "Elliott Wave peaks and troughs detected!"
End Sub
```

### Explanation of the Code:

- **Data Loading**: The code loads price data from Column A into an array.
- **Peak and Trough Detection**: It loops through the data to find local maxima (peaks) and minima (troughs).
- **Output**: The detected peaks and troughs are written to Columns C and D, respectively.

### Limitations:

1. **Basic Detection**: This code only detects local peaks and troughs. It does not implement the full Elliott Wave Theory, which requires more sophisticated pattern recognition.
2. **No Wave Counting**: The code does not count or label the waves according to Elliott Wave Theory.
3. **Market Conditions**: The detection may not be accurate in volatile or sideways markets.

### Next Steps:

To enhance this code, consider implementing:
- More sophisticated algorithms for wave counting.
- Additional checks for wave structure (e.g., wave ratios).
- Visualization of detected waves on a chart.

Elliott Wave analysis can be quite subjective, so be prepared to refine your approach based on your specific needs and the characteristics of the data you are analyzing.

Writing a VBA script to automatically detect Elliott waves in financial data can be a challenging task, as it requires a deep understanding of the Elliott wave theory and its application to financial markets. However, I can provide a general outline of the steps involved in creating such a script.

1. Data Collection: Collect historical price and volume data for the financial instrument you want to analyze. This data can be obtained from sources such as stock exchanges, financial databases, or online data providers.
2. Data Preprocessing: Clean and preprocess the data to ensure it is in a format that can be easily analyzed. This may include removing missing values, handling outliers, and normalizing the data.
3. Identify Trends: Use a trend identification algorithm to identify the overall direction and strength of the market trend. This can be done using techniques such as moving averages, momentum indicators, or other technical indicators.
4. Identify Corrective Waves: Identify corrective waves, which are countertrend movements that occur within a trend. These waves can be identified by analyzing the price action and volume data to identify patterns such as zigzags, flats, or triangles.
5. Identify Impulse Waves: Identify impulse waves, which are the main trend waves that move in the direction of the overall trend. These waves can be identified by analyzing the price action and volume data to identify patterns such as impulse waves, extensions, or truncations.
6. Analyze Wave Structures: Analyze the wave structures to identify the specific Elliott wave pattern that is unfolding. This can be done by identifying the characteristics of each wave, such as its duration, amplitude, and slope, and comparing them to the characteristics of known Elliott wave patterns.
7. Generate Signals: Generate buy and sell signals based on the identified Elliott wave pattern. For example, a buy signal may be generated when a new impulse wave is identified, while a sell signal may be generated when a corrective wave is identified.
8. Implement Risk Management: Implement risk management strategies to protect your capital and maximize your returns. This may include setting stop-loss levels, limiting position size, and diversifying your portfolio.
9. Test and Refine: Test your VBA script on historical data and refine it as needed to improve its accuracy and performance. This may involve adjusting parameters, adding new features, or optimizing the code for faster execution.
10. Deploy: Once you are satisfied with the performance of your VBA script, you can deploy it in your trading environment to automatically detect Elliott waves and generate trading signals.

Note that this is a high-level overview of the steps involved in creating a VBA script to detect Elliott waves. The specific details and implementation will depend on your programming skills, data sources, and trading strategies. It is also important to note that Elliott wave analysis is a complex and subjective technique, and there may be different interpretations of the same data. Therefore, it is essential to thoroughly backtest and validate your script before using it in live trading.

Writing a VBA macro to automatically detect Elliott waves involves a few steps:

1. Firstly, you need to identify the time frame and the type of chart you want to analyze. You may want to choose a daily or weekly chart for your analysis.
2. Next, you need to define the rules for identifying the Elliott waves. These rules include identifying the high and low points of each wave and identifying the wave pattern.
3. You can use the following code as a starting point for your macro:
```vbnet
'Set the time frame and chart type
Dim chartType As String
chartType = "Daily" 'or "Weekly"

'Set the time frame range
Dim startDate As Date, endDate As Date
startDate = #1/1/2022#
endDate = #31/12/2022#

'Get the chart object
Dim chartObj As Chart
Set chartObj = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Sheet1").Shapes("Chart1").Chart
chartObj.SetSourceData Source:=Range("A1:B100")
chartObj.HasTitle = True
chartObj.Title.Text = "Elliott Waves"
chartObj.HasLegend = True
chartObj.legend.Text = "TradingView"

'Set the time frame
chartObj.Axes(xlCategory).AxisFormat = xlTime
chartObj.Axes(xlCategory).TimeScale.Time.Start = startDate
chartObj.Axes(xlCategory).TimeScale.Time.End = endDate

'Set the chart style
chartObj.Chart.SetSourceData Source:=Range("A1:B100")
With chartObj.Chart
    .Style = xlChartsStyleSheet17
    .ChartAreas(1).Axis(xlCategory).MajorGridlines.ColorIndex = 2
    .ChartAreas(1).Axis(xlCategory).MajorGridlines.visible = False
    .ChartAreas(1).Axis(xlCategory).MinorGridlines.ColorIndex = 2
    .ChartAreas(1).Axis(xlCategory).MinorGridlines.visible = False
End With

'Define the wave rules
Dim waveType As String
waveType = "Bullish"
Dim highPoint As Double, lowPoint As Double
highPoint = 50
lowPoint = 10

'Draw the wave pattern
Dim startIndex As Integer, endIndex As Integer, waveWidth As Integer, waveHeight As Integer, angle As Double
Dim waveType As String
waveType = "Bullish"
Dim highPoint As Double, lowPoint As Double, lineStart As Integer
highPoint = 50
lowPoint = 10
lineStart = 1
 With chartObj.Chart
    startIndex = -1
    For i = 1 To 7
        startIndex = i
        lineStart = i - 1
        waveWidth = 3
        waveHeight = 2.5
        For j = startIndex To lineStart
            With chartObj.Chart
                point = chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(j)
                point.IsSelected = False
                If point.y > highPoint Then
                    highPoint = point.y
                    endIndex = j
                End If
                If point.y < lowPoint Then
                    lowPoint = point.y
                    waveType = waveType
                    angle = (lowPoint - highPoint) / (lowPoint - startIndex)
                    waveWidth = 3
                    waveHeight = highPoint - lowPoint
                    Start:=chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(j).x
                    End:=chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(endIndex).x
                    With DrawingObjects(1, 1).Ellipse
                        .SetLeft:=Start - 1
                        .SetTop:=lineStart
                        .SetWidth:=waveWidth
                        .SetHeight:=waveHeight
                        .SetFillColor RGB(224, 102, 167)
                    End With
                End If
            End With
        Next j
        lineStart = lineStart + 1
    Next i
    waveType = ""
End With

'Define the wave rules
waveType = "Bearish"
highPoint = 50
lowPoint = 10

    startIndex = -1
    For i = 1 To 7
        startIndex = i

        For j = startIndex To lineStart
            With chartObj.Chart
                point = chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(j)
                point.IsSelected = False
                If point.y < highPoint Then
                    highPoint = point.y
                    endIndex = j
                End If
                If point.y > lowPoint Then
                    lowPoint = point.y
                    waveType = waveType

                    waveWidth = 3

                    Start:=chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(j).x
                    End:=chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(endIndex).x
                    With DrawingObjects(1, 1).Ellipse
                        .SetLeft:=Start - 1

                        .SetWidth:=waveWidth

                        .SetFillColor RGB(167, 98, 224)
                    End With
                End If
            End With
        Next j
        lineStart = lineStart + 1
    Next i
    waveType = ""
End With

'Define the wave rules
waveType = "Tradingview"
highPoint = 50
lowPoint = 10

    startIndex = -1
    For i = 1 To 7
        startIndex = i

End With

'Define the wave rules

highPoint = 50
lowPoint = 10

 With chartObj.Chart
    startIndex = -1
    For i = 1 To 7
        startIndex = i
        lineStart = i - 1

        For j = startIndex To lineStart
            With chartObj.Chart
                point = chartObj.SeriesCollections(1).Points(j)

End With
```

1. Import price data into Excel
2. Identify significant highs and lows
3. Analyze the wave structure
4. Label potential Elliott Waves

Here's a sample VBA code to get you started:

```vba
Sub DetectElliottWaves()
    Dim ws As Worksheet
    Dim lastRow As Long
    Dim i As Long
    Dim highPoints() As Double
    Dim lowPoints() As Double
    Dim waveCount As Integer
    
    ' Set the active worksheet
    Set ws = ActiveSheet
    
    ' Find the last row with data
    lastRow = ws.Cells(ws.Rows.Count, "A").End(xlUp).Row
    
    ' Initialize arrays to store high and low points
    ReDim highPoints(1 To lastRow)
    ReDim lowPoints(1 To lastRow)
    
    ' Identify significant highs and lows
    For i = 2 To lastRow
        If ws.Cells(i, 2).Value > ws.Cells(i - 1, 2).Value And ws.Cells(i, 2).Value > ws.Cells(i + 1, 2).Value Then
            highPoints(i) = ws.Cells(i, 2).Value
        ElseIf ws.Cells(i, 3).Value < ws.Cells(i - 1, 3).Value And ws.Cells(i, 3).Value < ws.Cells(i + 1, 3).Value Then
            lowPoints(i) = ws.Cells(i, 3).Value
        End If
    Next i
    
    ' Analyze wave structure and label potential Elliott Waves
    waveCount = 0
    For i = 2 To lastRow
        If highPoints(i) > 0 Then
            waveCount = waveCount + 1
            ws.Cells(i, 4).Value = "Wave " & waveCount & " (High)"
        ElseIf lowPoints(i) > 0 Then
            waveCount = waveCount + 1
            ws.Cells(i, 4).Value = "Wave " & waveCount & " (Low)"
        End If
        
        ' Reset wave count after 5 waves
        If waveCount = 5 Then
            waveCount = 0
        End If
    Next i
    
    MsgBox "Elliott Wave detection complete!"
End Sub
```

This script does the following:

1. Identifies significant highs and lows in the price data.
2. Labels potential Elliott Waves based on these highs and lows.
3. Resets the wave count after every 5 waves (assuming a basic 5-wave structure).

To use this script:

1. Ensure your price data is in columns A (date), B (high), and C (low).
2. The script will output potential wave labels in column D.

Please note that this is a very basic implementation and does not account for many of the nuances and rules of Elliott Wave Theory. To create a more accurate Elliott Wave detection system, you would need to incorporate additional rules and guidelines, such as:

- Wave relationships and proportions
- Fibonacci retracements and extensions
- Alternation principle
- Channel analysis
- Time analysis

Additionally, you might want to consider using more advanced techniques like machine learning algorithms to improve pattern recognition and accuracy.

Remember that Elliott Wave analysis is complex and often subjective, so any automated system should be used in conjunction with other technical analysis tools and human judgment.

c. Recursively call `sum_array` for the subarray `array[mididx:stopidx)` and store the result in the `x1` register.
d. Compute the sum `s` of the subarrays by adding the results (`s = x0 + x1`).

Here's the implementation of the `sum_array` function in AArch64 assembly language, which calculates the sum of elements in an array recursively. The function takes three parameters: the address of the duplicate array, the starting index, and the stopping index. It saves these parameters onto the stack before making the recursive call and retrieves them afterward.

```assembly
.type sum_array, @function

    stp x29, x30, [sp, #-16]! // function prolog
    mov x29, sp                // set frame pointer

    // Save parameters on the stack

    str x2, [sp, #-8]!         // Save stopidx

    ldr x2, [sp], #8           // Load stopidx

    ldr w3, [x0, x1, lsl 2]    // Load dup_array[startidx]

    bl sum_array               // Recursive call

    add x0, x0, x3             // Add dup_array[startidx] to the result
    b end_sum_array            // Jump to end

base_case:
    mov x0, #0                  // Return 0 for base case

end_sum_array:
    ldp x29, x30, [sp], #16     // function epilog
    ret
```

2. **Parameter Saving**: The parameters (array address, start index, and stop index) are saved onto the stack for later retrieval.

6. **Adding the Current Element**: After the recursive call returns, the current element is added to the result of the recursive call.
7. **Function Epilog**: Finally, the function restores the link register and frame pointer from the stack before returning.

```python
class SyntaxAnalyzer:
    def __init__(self):
        self.grammar = {
            'S': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E', 'F', 'G', 'H'],
            'A': ['arithmetic_expression'],
            'B': ['assignment_expression'],
            'C': ['comma_expression'],
            'D': ['relation_expression'],
            'E': ['logical_expression'],
            'F': ['loop_statement'],
            'G': ['select_statement'],
            'H': ['jump_statement'],
            'I': ['function_call_statement'],
            'arithmetic_expression': ['operand', 'operator', 'operand'],
            'assignment_expression': ['variable', '=', 'expression'],
            'comma_expression': ['expression', ',', 'expression'],
            'relation_expression': ['operand', 'relation_operator', 'operand'],
            'logical_expression': ['expression', 'logical_operator', 'expression'],
            # Add more rules as needed
        }
        self.first_sets = {}
        self.follow_sets = {}
        self.parse_table = {}
        self.input_tokens = []
        self.errors = []

        pass

    def parse(self, tokens):
        self.input_tokens = tokens
        stack = ['S']
        index = 0

        while stack:
            top = stack.pop()
            if top in self.grammar:  # Non-terminal
                production = self.parse_table.get(top, {}).get(self.input_tokens[index])
                if production:
                    stack.extend(reversed(production))
                else:
                    self.errors.append(f"Error: No production for {top} with token {self.input_tokens[index]}")
                    return False
            elif top == self.input_tokens[index]:  # Terminal
                index += 1
            else:
                self.errors.append(f"Error: Expected {top}, found {self.input_tokens[index]}")
                return False

        return index == len(self.input_tokens)

    def visualize(self):
        print("FIRST Sets:")
        for non_terminal, first_set in self.first_sets.items():
            print(f"FIRST({non_terminal}) = {first_set}")

        print("\nFOLLOW Sets:")
        for non_terminal, follow_set in self.follow_sets.items():
            print(f"FOLLOW({non_terminal}) = {follow_set}")

        print("\nParse Table:")
        for non_terminal, productions in self.parse_table.items():
            for token, production in productions.items():
                print(f"{non_terminal} -> {production} on {token}")

        if self.errors:
            print("\nErrors:")
            for error in self.errors:
                print(error)
```

```
//192.168.0.116/tv /mnt/plex/hd1 cifs credentials=/path/to/credentials,file_mode=0777,dir_mode=0777,uid=1000,gid=1000 0 0
```

Here's a PineScript code for a BTCUSD indicator with buy and sell signals based on the Supertrend, Dziwne, and QQE indicators:

```pine
//@version=4
study("BTCUSD Indicator", overlay=true)

// Input parameters
atrPeriod = input(14, title="ATR Period")
atrMultiplier = input(3.0, title="ATR Multiplier")
useAtrTp = input(true, title="Use ATR for Take Profit")
tpPercentage = input(1.0, title="Take Profit Percentage", minval=0.1, step=0.1)

// Supertrend
[supertrend, direction] = supertrend(atrPeriod, atrMultiplier)

// Dziwne
dziwneLength = input(14, title="Dziwne Length")
dziwneSource = input(close, title="Dziwne Source")
dziwne = ema(dziwneSource, dziwneLength)
dziwneUp = dziwne > dziwne[1]
dziwneDown = dziwne < dziwne[1]

// QQE
qQELength = input(14, title="QQE Length")
qQESource = input(close, title="QQE Source")
qQE = ema(qQESource, qQELength)
qQEUp = qQE > qQE[1]
qQEDown = qQE < qQE[1]

// Buy signal
buySignal = direction == 1 and dziwneUp and qQEUp

// Sell signal
sellSignal = direction == -1 and dziwneDown and qQEDown

// Take Profit
tpLevel = useAtrTp ? atr(atrPeriod) : close * (1 + tpPercentage / 100)

// Plot signals
plotshape(buySignal, title="Buy Signal", location=location.belowbar, style=shape.triangleup, size=size.small, color=color.green)
plotshape(sellSignal, title="Sell Signal", location=location.abovebar, style=shape.triangledown, size=size.small, color=color.red)

// Plot Take Profit level
plot(buySignal ? tpLevel : na, title="Take Profit", style=plot.style_linebr, color=color.green, linewidth=1)
plot(sellSignal ? tpLevel : na, title="Take Profit", style=plot.style_linebr, color=color.red, linewidth=1)
```

This code combines the Supertrend, Dziwne, and QQE indicators to generate buy and sell signals for the BTCUSD pair. Here's how it works:

1. The Supertrend indicator is used to determine the overall trend direction. When the Supertrend is green, it indicates a bullish trend, and when it's red, it indicates a bearish trend.

2. The Dziwne indicator is used to confirm the trend. If Dziwne is in a long trend (green), it confirms a bullish trend, and if it's in a short trend (red), it confirms a bearish trend.

3. The QQE indicator is used as an additional confirmation. If QQE is in the blue zone, it confirms a bullish trend, and if it's in the red zone, it confirms a bearish trend.

4. A buy signal is generated when the Supertrend is green, Dziwne is in a long trend (green), and QQE is in the blue zone.

5. A sell signal is generated when the Supertrend is red, Dziwne is in a short trend (red), and QQE is in the red zone.

6. The take profit level is calculated based on either the ATR (Average True Range) or a percentage of the closing price, depending on the user's input.

7. The buy and sell signals are plotted on the chart using triangles, and the take profit levels are plotted as lines.

Please note that this is a basic implementation, and you may need to adjust the input parameters and customize the code further based on your specific requirements and trading strategy.

Creating a TradingView Pine Script that incorporates the Supertrend, Dziwne, and QQE indicators for trading BTC/USD involves several steps. Below is a simplified version of a Pine Script that implements the strategy you described. Please note that you may need to adjust the parameters and settings according to your specific trading preferences.

```pinescript
//@version=5
indicator("BTCUSD Trading Strategy", overlay=true)

// Supertrend parameters
atrPeriod = input(10, title="ATR Period")
factor = input(3.0, title="Factor")
[supertrend, direction] = ta.supertrend(factor, atrPeriod)

// Dziwne parameters (assuming a simple moving average for demonstration)
dziwneLength = input(14, title="Dziwne Length")
dziwne = ta.sma(close, dziwneLength)

// QQE parameters
qqeLength = input(14, title="QQE Length")
rsiValue = ta.rsi(close, qqeLength)
wilders = ta.wma(rsiValue, qqeLength)
qqe = wilders * 0.5 // Simplified QQE calculation for demonstration

// Buy and Sell conditions
longCondition = (direction == 1) and (dziwne > close) and (qqe > 50)
shortCondition = (direction == -1) and (dziwne < close) and (qqe < 50)

// Plotting signals on the chart
plotshape(series=longCondition, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, style=shape.labelup, text="BUY")
plotshape(series=shortCondition, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, style=shape.labeldown, text="SELL")

// Take Profit (TP) using ATR
atrValue = ta.atr(atrPeriod)
longTP = close + atrValue * 1.5 // Adjust multiplier as needed
shortTP = close - atrValue * 1.5 // Adjust multiplier as needed

// Plotting TP levels
plot(longTP, color=color.green, style=plot.style_stepline, title="Long TP")
plot(shortTP, color=color.red, style=plot.style_stepline, title="Short TP")

// Background color for trend indication
bgcolor(direction == 1 ? color.new(color.green, 90) : na)
bgcolor(direction == -1 ? color.new(color.red, 90) : na)
```

### Explanation of the Code:
1. **Supertrend Calculation**: The Supertrend indicator is calculated using the ATR (Average True Range) and a multiplier factor.
2. **Dziwne Calculation**: For demonstration purposes, a simple moving average is used as a placeholder for the Dziwne indicator. You may replace this with the actual Dziwne calculation.
3. **QQE Calculation**: A simplified version of the QQE is calculated using the RSI and a Wilder's moving average. You may need to implement the full QQE calculation based on your requirements.
4. **Buy and Sell Conditions**: The script checks for conditions to enter long or short positions based on the indicators.
5. **Take Profit Levels**: TP levels are calculated using the ATR. You can adjust the multiplier based on your risk management strategy.
6. **Signal Plotting**: Buy and sell signals are plotted on the chart using shapes.
7. **Background Color**: The background color changes based on the trend direction.

### Note:
- This script is a basic implementation and may require further refinement based on the actual Dziwne and QQE calculations.
- Always backtest your strategy before using it in live trading to ensure its effectiveness and to understand its risk profile.
- Adjust the parameters according to your trading style and risk tolerance.

Sure, here's a possible PineScript code for a trading view indicator that implements the strategy you described:
```
// Inputs

supertrend = SMA(close, length) > SMA(close, 2 * length)
dziwne = Dziwne(close, length)
qqe = QQE(close, length)

// Define the Trend Indicator A-V2 and Trend Indicator B-V2
trendA = TrendIndicatorA(close, length)
trendB = TrendIndicatorB(close, length)

// Buy and sell signals

sellSignal = crossunder(supertrend, dziwne) and crossunder(trendA, trendB)

// Plot the indicators and signals

plot(dziwne ? 1 : 0, "Dziwne", color.green, 9)
plot(qqe ? 1 : 0, "QQE", color.green, 9)

plot(trendB ? 1 : 0, "Trend Indicator B-V2", color.blue, 9)
plotshape(buySignal ? 1 : 0, "Buy Signal", shape.arrowup, location.belowbar, color.green, size.small)
plotshape(sellSignal ? 1 : 0, "Sell Signal", shape.arrowdown, location.abovebar, color.red, size.small)

// Add title and labels

label("Buy", y = 10)
label("Sell", y = 8)
```
This code uses the `SMA` function to calculate the Supertrend, Dziwne, and QQE indicators, and the `TrendIndicatorA` and `TrendIndicatorB` functions to calculate the Trend Indicator A-V2 and Trend Indicator B-V2. The `crossover` and `crossunder` functions are used to check for buy and sell signals, respectively. The `plot` function is used to plot the indicators and signals, and the `plotshape` function is used to plot the buy and sell signals as arrows. Finally, the `title` and `label` functions are used to add a title and labels to the chart.

As for the `TrendIndicatorA` and `TrendIndicatorB` functions, they are defined as follows:
```

TrendIndicatorA = (close - SMA(close, length)) / (SMA(close, 2 * length) - SMA(close, length))

// Trend Indicator B-V2
TrendIndicatorB = (close - SMA(close, length)) / (SMA(close, 2 * length) - SMA(close, length)) * (1 + (SMA(close, length) - SMA(close, 2 * length)) / (SMA(close, length) - SMA(close, 2 * length)))
```
These functions use the `SMA` function to calculate the smoothed price data, and then calculate the trend indicators using a combination of division and multiplication. The `TrendIndicatorA` function is a simpler version that uses a single smoothing length, while the `TrendIndicatorB` function is a more complex version that uses two smoothing lengths and includes an additional factor to adjust the signal strength.

As for the `Dziwne` indicator, it is defined as follows:
```
// Dziwne
Dziwne = (close - SMA(close, length)) / (SMA(close, 2 * length) - SMA(close, length)) * (1 + (SMA(close, length) - SMA(close, 2 * length)) / (SMA(close, length) - SMA(close, 2 * length)))
```
This function is similar to the `TrendIndicatorB` function, but it uses a different formula to calculate the trend indicator.

As for the `QQE` indicator, it is defined as follows:
```
// QQE
QQE = (close - SMA(close, length)) / (SMA(close, 2 * length) - SMA(close, length))
```
This function is similar to the `TrendIndicatorA` function, but it uses a different formula to calculate the trend indicator.

11. Steam Tunnels
Program Name: Tunnels.java Input File: tunnels.dat
UT is a huge organization both in number of people and in physical size. The campus has its own
power plants and utilities because it is cheaper to run them independently rather than buy power
from the city of Austin. Part of the UT utility system is a network of steam tunnels that connects
buildings underground. Urban legends claim students go spelunking in these tunnels. Not an
advisable activity but CS students have always had an "affinity for disobedience."
Write a program that determines how many distinct parts exist in a given section of the steam
tunnel system. A steam tunnel section is described as follows:
G = {WEL,BUR,RLM,GTS,DEL,UTC,WCH},{WEL,BUR},{WEL,RLM},{GTS,DEL},
{BUR,RLM},{RLM,WEL},{GTS,DEL},{UTC,BUR}
The first set of brackets contains the buildings in the section. This is followed by building pairs
that indicate a tunnel exists between the two buildings in the pair. A part is any set of buildings
that are connected by tunnels, directly or indirectly.
The section described above consist of 3 distinct parts, the (WEL, BUR, RLM) part, the (GTS,
DEL) part, and the (WCH) part.
Input
• The first line contains a single integer N that indicates the number of data sets.
• Each data set consists of a single line. The first part of each data set is a list of the
buildings in the section. Buildings will be distinct in the list for a given data set.
• The list of buildings in the data set is followed by pairs of buildings. Each pair indicates a
tunnel exists between the two buildings. All buildings in the pairs will be present in the
list at the start of the data set. Buildings names consist of one or more characters.
Building names will not contain braces, commas, or spaces.
• There will be at least one building per data set. There may be zero tunnels for a data set.
Tunnels may exist that connect a building to itself
• Brackets and commas are used to separate the initial list and pairs of buildings as shown
above. There will be no extraneous spaces in the data set.
WEL BUR
RLM
GTS
DEL
UTC WCH

For each data set print out the number of separate parts that exist in the steam tunnel section
represented by the data set.
